reviewText:
Early Access Review

If I could take one game with me to a desert island, it'd be Caves of Qud.

**DIFFICULTY**
Is it hard? Yes.
Is it too hard? No.
Even for somebody who's never played a roguelike before? Totally do-able.
You will die. A lot. The game is designed to be hard, but not tear-your-hair-out frustrating. The way that it manages to be very difficult and yet wholly enjoyable despite death after death is a masterpiece of gaming.

**INTRIGUE**
There is deep political simulation, effecting every last mob in the game. Gain enough reputation with certain types of creatures or people (arachnids, farmers, tortoises) and they will rush to your aid in battle. Lose enough, and they'll attack you on sight. The landmarks in the game--like the starting village, Joppa--are always the same, but the wilderness and caves are procedurally-generated. That means that as you try to reach the deepest depths of, say, Red Rock, you could find the next staircase down mere feet away or on the other side of the map. What's more, there are very in-depth and extremely interesting crafting and trade systems that you can master in time.

**COMBAT**
Deceptively simple. Like any proper roguelike, you have to come up with creative ways to deal with certain situations. Choosing whether to shoot your rifle or swing your sword could be a life or death decision. It's easy to learn, hard to master.

**CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION**
Oh, boy. Wanna be a beguilin', time-dilatin', flame-throwin', photosynthesizin', gunslingin' cowboy-snake called Grassy Jones? You got it.
Want to be one of just a few remaining true men, an aristocrat as well versed in ways of the trigger as he is in the way of the blade? You got it.
Wanna get a few more points to put into useful mutations by taking a debuff that puts an evil twin somewhere in the world, an exact clone of your character who may one day find you and kill you? Yep. You can do that too.

**LORE**
Just play it, man. It's awesome.

**CONS**
Sometimes, you get attached to your beguilin', time-dilatin', flame-throwin', photosynthesizin', gunslingin' cowboy-snake called Grassy Jones. While after he dies you can click 'replay most recent character' on the new game screen and get Grassy Jones back, you won't get his successes back. Half the time, that's fine and it's just as fun to do it all over again. There's actually a disable permadeath button, but for now it doesn't work. There are other little cons, but they're too small to mention.

**THE BEST PART**
It ain't even finished yet, cowboy.

I had never actually seen a madpole before. Even the best hunters in Kyakukya would talk about them as merciless killing machines.

The thing looked as mean as they said. Rows of jagged teeth flashed between frantic snapping as it splashed about. I watched from the banks of the river a few feet away, peering down my carbine's scope to get a closer look. It was ugly.

I pulled the trigger; the madpole tried to flee, but another pull and the water turned red around its corpse. Three more madpoles swam over. I shot another and they scattered. I emptied my carbine, reloaded, and saw that only one was still moving.

Feeling sporting, I shouldered my rifle and drew my daggers. I waded into the river and charged the last madpole, landing both blades in either side.

You can imagine my surprise when this madpole ignored the blades I planted, latched onto my shell, and I could feel its teeth through my carapace. The very same carapace had, just last moon, merely sizzled as laser fire hit me.

Even more surprising was watching my right arm come off in the madpole's mouth, then fall into the water as the madpole took another attempt at ripping my shell from my body.

I stabbed as hard as I could with my remaining arm to try to dislodge the madpole. This worked, in a way; the madpole released in order to gnaw at my feet, shearing them off with such speed that my terror obscured my pain. My remaining forearm was taken off at the elbow.

Rolling myself onto the bank of the river, the madpole released me to fall back into the water lest he suffocate on land. I rummaged through my now thoroughly-bloody pack with a stump and my face; I found it: My last shot of Ubernostrum.

Held in my teeth, I shot my bicep-stump full of superdrugs and watched as my arm sprouted back, as painfully as it did quickly.

I dug out my revolver, shot the remaining madpole to death, and collapsed. I decided to wait and wash my bag as I waited for my natural mutant regeneration to generate bones and sinew to regrow my limbs, and to reseal my carapace where the madpole had bitten through.

I dined on my severed feet while I waited.

Caves of Qud is a truly amazing roguelike, developed over a 10+ year period by two guys and a ton of love. While most people think wizards and dragons when they hear the term roguelike, CoQ instead brings the world to a post-apocalyptic setting somewhere on the planet earth.

At this point in the distant future, much of the land is a vast salt-desert, interspersed with jungles, mountains and more. The remaining humans and mutants (and even weirder creatures) struggle to survive, traversing the brutal heat and unforgiving landscape with the hope that maybe this settlement will last. Water is the currency of choice; with so much of the land arid, clean water is rare and since life depends on it, unbelivably precious as well. Yet beings have survived and thrived, and the game presents a huge amount of lore in various forms to reflect this.
Alongside the history is the present, with all the fracturing of groups and the different factions that result from a collapse of modern society. Species hate other species, religions hate other religions, and sometimes the enemy of my enemy is my friend. CoQ has a layered faction system, where the player's actions (and even equipment) can change their standing in the eyes of the denizens of the world.
And with the amount of character customization, your choices will have an impact. From the true humans, non-mutants of various castes and professions, to the mutants, with the huge amount of physical and mental positive and negative mutations, the game can be approached in a vast amount of ways. The specifics are covered elsewhere, but know that builds can go from traditional gunslingers to four-armed, two heart furry ape-like creatures that leak slime and occasionally warp in and out of existence. It's even possible to be hunted by an evil, alternate-dimension version of yourself.

What makes Caves of Qud so engrossing and keeps it from collapsing under the weight of the huge amount of features is the streamlining of the classic roguelike experience, especially in regards to the UI. Things just make sense. Very rarely will the game fight against the player, instead they're allowed to lose themselves in the world of Qud. This is even apparent in the graphics; light is cast and blocked by different things, smoke curls and acid spreads, and water will splash as the player runs through.
The game now offers tiles, though I'm personally a fan of the ASCII setting after playing it for so long. That doesn't mean the tiles are bad though; in fact it's quite the opposite. Items and enemies are easy to identify, there are various settings to tweak how it looks, and even a fair amount of performance options for players on older computers. It even has music slowly being added, though no sound effects currently. It also supports user mods, for the players who want to add their own changes to the game.



A final note: Caves of Qud is definitely following the footsteps of traditional roguelikes. The term has been diluted to mean permadeath and maybe randomly generated dungeons, so you can end up with a realtime side scrolling platformer with permadeath being labeled roguelike". This is not one of those. It's turn-based

Early Access Review

Full disclosure: I've been playing the alpha of this game since 2012, and got a free copy from the developer.

Caves of Qud is a roguelike along the lines of ADOM. There's random dungeons, a set storyline, traditional gameplay, sure. But what makes Caves of Qud stand out amongst the crowd is the sheer mystique of the setting - Qud is a dangerous country in a post-apocalyptic era. Most of the humans (potentially including you) are mutants with strange powers that grant interesting tactical choices. The areas feel extremely unique (a rarity in the roguelike genre) - one area has you rushing to the bottom of a pit on conveyor belts while trying to avoid the toxic inhabitants, another area has a strange mix of machine-worshipping humans and armored trolls in a cyrogenic environment with optional frozen bosses... the list goes on.

Character customization is also neat. Beyond mutations, there's also skills, a crafting system, faction relations... It's a bit overwhelming at first. It is fun to eventually grow into a winged psychic with a flamethrower that has a poor relationship with the consortium of plants!

The combat is by far the neatest thing I've seen in a traditional roguelike. Most of the skills and spells have neat effects tied onto them, and most of the enemies have interesting behavior with their abilities. There's a ton of tactics involved, and mashing the basic attack of moving into enemies is a sure way to die past a certain point in the game.

Being a roguelike, there is permadeath, BUT you can turn it off if you wanted to. But hey, what kinda roguelike doesn't have permadeath?

It's also reeeeally difficult. It took me a ton of tries just to get a character past a certain point in the game. Some of it has been rebalanced in the alpha, but you should still prepare to die. And die. And die.

The major gripes I have with this game are its memory issues (which I'm told are being fixed) and that the tiles can make things look really similar (which can be turned off). It's also still unfinished, so there's that too (though it still takes ~5 hours to beat if you don't die. Protip: you will die).

Conclusions:
+ Excellent lore, setting
+ Really cool character customization
+ Interesting combat
+ Togglable permadeath
+/- Pretty difficult
- Memory issues
- Tiles make everything look really similar (togglable)
- It's still in early accessm, so it's unfinished

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had a positive review up for ages, but looked and saw it wasn't very specific. so let's clarify!

CoQ has been releasing free builds for at least six years, and went live on Steam in, eh, late 2015? the first thing to note about it is that, unlike most roguelikes in a similar graphical style, it has a thoroughly user-friend interface, and in fact the graphics are clear enough that even someone like me who can never bother to try could read it in ASCII. that's no longer necessary, as the released version sports a very stylish and stylized tileset, but it speaks to the deliberateness of the design.

that relative transparency is all over in CoQ. important mechanics aren't usually obfuscated; a piece of armor modifies your damage resistance and your dodge chance, and if it does anything else, a quick examination will tell you what it is. dialogue plays out as trees rather than keyword guessing, and you're given clear guidance on how to get going right out of the gate, while also having several directions you can go--or being free to wander on your own. the game is narrative and lore is plentiful, its far-future apocalypse rich in a kind of charming strangeness that pulls off the trick of never winking at itself. these characters genuinely do live in a weird and mostly posthuman world.

one of the earliest jobs you're sent on is named for Canticle for Liebowitz, and you can definitely see that in the tone. the wreckage of ancient technology's everywhere, sometimes an object of worship, sometimes of study, sometimes of something in between, but people who understand it are eccentrics. you'll occasionally come across a tome that describes some menacing discovery in pure science from the distant past and implies with gloriously heady and incoherent diction just how the world was saved from that dark knowledge. the world's at once ruined and lively. and when you go into the jungle and the recently-added ambient tracks kick in, you'll realize it's filled with menace, too.

if there's a criticism to be laid at Qud's feet, it's that it can be hard. character build guides can go a long way to help with that--the freeform system mean it's easy to build a character who's useless, although there are still tons of ways to build one who's useful--but ultimately until you've spent a bit of time with the game you're still going to be stepping on plants that impale you and end a run you though was promising. recycling your previous build is generally pretty easy, but going through the motions of starting out can be a tiny bit annoying--reassigning whatever psychic powers you chose to take to keybindings, running around town to pick up whatever randomly-spawned loot you've got this time. ultimately, though, these are small and self-afflicted tribulations, and do nothing to diminish what I feel is the best roguelike around.

Have you ever played a classic roguelike? I'm talking NetHack, ADOM, Dungeon Crawl, any of the games that started life as a nigh-incomprehensible block of ASCII characters. Old roguelikes were big on randomization but low on approachability, requiring you to know all sorts of interactions and tricks and symbols just to avoid dying to a bird or something. Caves of Qud plays like a classic roguelike that prioritizes fun over tricks, and does so with a unique setting and sense of style.

Character creation is a major highlight in Qud, allowing you to pick more than just attributes and a class (though even the classes are extremely interesting and varied). Being a post-apocalyptic sci-fi sort of game, you get to be a mutant if you want (yes, you want) and pick special powers from a hefty list of dozens. There's everything from telepathy and night vision to multiple limbs, flight, temporal clones, and mind crushing. These powers are on pretty generous cooldowns, and give you a wealth of tactical options in the game that a lot of roguelikes don't offer. My current best is a four-armed spastic teleporting rogue-thing that can emit sleeping gas or EMPs in emergencies, and I love him to the bits he will eventually be.

Once your character is made, you get dropped in the little town of Joppa with some intro quests to do and houses to loot. The quests in Qud give some much-needed direction, as the world is quite wide-open and there's plenty of places to get lost and die in. Dungeons are varied between caves, ruins, and higher-tech locales, and you can indeed get lost in the jungles and canyons between them. These places are populated with a colorful cast of creatures including rust crabs, goat men, and sentient ooze. The simple graphics are clear enough to distinguish the people and critters you encounter, and a very helpful Look function gives you all the information you need to know about approaching something new.

If it seems like I'm gushing about Qud, it's because I've never played a roguelike with so much depth and discovery that, at the same time, has so many user-friendly features. The menus are dense and busy but display everything you need to know in sensible order and with useful icons and colors. Item, skill, and attribute descriptions leave nothing to the imagination, so you'll never be left wondering where you should spend your points. And the quests really are fantastic signposts for the game, giving you more to do than the simple descend and find the doodad" premises of the classic roguelikes.

It's not a perfect package

reviewText:
Early Access Review

STORY/SETTING:
The environment and world that this game is set in are awesome. A post-apocalyptic setting done right with a minimum of over-used tropes is the backdrop for your adventure. You begin as a hapless adventurer simply trying to make your way in life, but can progress (with a little luck and a little skill) into a wealthy and powerful figure with an ever-increasing knowledge of the mysterious world in which you live and its exciting ancient past. 10/10.

UI:
Once you grasp the basics of the control scheme, the game becomes easier and easier to play. I personally enjoy the all-keyboard control scheme of a well-made roguelike, as it allows me to play the entire game with no more hand motion than it takes me to write this review. This setup can be daunting for newcomers to the roguelike genre or even to experienced dungeon crawlers who are new to this game in particular. The complete lack of mouse support, even in the menus, has been off-putting at times; however, there is an option in one of the menus that claims to activate mouse interactivity (though it seems to do nothing at the time). Perhaps the developers are planning on introducing this feature at some point in the future.
The game includes no tutorial for the controls, so a new player has to do some reading and some perusing of the hotkey binding page before they can make much progress in the game. I would hope that at some point in the future the devs introduce some sort of tutorial mode to help out with this.
Overall, once the controls are mastered and the GUI is understood by the player, it is a system on par with what i would expect from a commercial roguelike, though it could definitely be daunting to a newbie and has no tutorial to explain its intricacies. 6/10.

GAMEPLAY:
As with the UI, there is no particular gameplay tutorial to help the player become immersed in the game. There are walls of text in the help menus that can, with patience, teach you enough about the game to get started. From there, you're on your own. In some ways, this is interesting, as it forces you to discover each new fact about the game world for yourself, rather than having it spoonfed to you. In other ways, it is frustrating. For example: it took me until my second or third character to understand that _water is the currency_ in this game. The confusion was due in large part to water's being represented by the $ sign in various interfaces.
That all being said, once one gets a grasp of the flow of gameplay, it's a wonderful experience that melds with the world and makes me want to play more and more. The procedurally generated game world also draws me in, as I know that playing the game will never simply become a matter of rote memorization. (Has anyone else played 400+ hours of Skyrim? Then you know the feeling.) Overall, 8/10.

CHARACTER OPTIONS:
The other daunting aspect for a new player is the sheer volume of choices to make at character creation, with no particular guidance besides (eventually) experience. Again, interesting in that one has to descover working character builds for themselves, but not newbie friendly. This item is double edged though: I have to say that I love nothing more than a system that gives me a full spectrum of options in character creation, especially in a world where having 4 unique classes" is a selling point in some games.

I'd recommend it at this state, with a small caveat. Caves of Qud is an amazing world that's incredibly interesting to explore plagued with one problem: you spend 95% of your games only exploring the first two caves. Unlike most roguelikes which generate the whole world, Caves of Qud only randomly generates the maps inside of it. You'll always start out in Joppa, and always get the same quests. And you'll probably die incredibly quickly if you don't follow those quests. Once you get out of the rut of doing the same things over and over again, the game is great. There is a small balance issue, in that ego-based characters essentially progress quadratically while physical mutation characters are essentially just better mid/late game than true hunams. Skills really never quite balance up to mutations, and high ego characters essentially get more mutations advancing quicker.

I should mention that my playtime is a little misleading. I've played maybe 50 or 60 hours more when it was free and not on steam. However, at least at this point in the development, the same problems still plague it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked this up because I was intrigued by the science-fantasy setting: the game takes place on what is presumably Earth, far in the future, amidst the ruins of a long-dead civilization that is now long dead, with the remnants of humanities scattered between various tribes and feudal holdfasts. It's a nice mix of ancient sensibilities and high-tech sorcery that hearkens back to a bygone era of pulp sci-fi.

Upon starting the game proper, I was pleasantly surprised by the level of customization permitted during character creations - mutant characters get the brunt of the options, in the forms of various mutations which can vary from small stat bonuses to special combat abilities to mutations that can drastically change the way the game is played. Pure humans, on the other hand, get to pick from one of several classes that will decide their starting skills and gear.

On entering the game world and getting into the thick of it, I somehow found my way to the faction page and found out that not only does each phylum of the animal kingdom have its own faction but that they're all after my blood, with the sole exception of the antelopes, with whom I've somehow managed to maintain cordial relations. On one of my trips to the beginners' dungeon, I was beset upon and ruthlessly torn apart by a pack of baboons, quickly confirming the faction screen's insinuations. The gameplay is the usual roguelike fare - delving into dungeons and fending off ravenous furries, robots and said fauna, collecting treasure (swords, axes, woven bracelets, shotguns, high-tech gizmos and combat drugs) and gaining levels.

The skill system in this game is well done - rather than gaining small incremental bonuses for pumping points into skills, every available upgrade to your skills carries a discrete benefit and/or ability. For example, when upgrading the long blades skill, you can choose the interception ability, which gives you a small chance of attacking any enemy that moves into an adjacent space for free and an activated stance that ensures you automatically intercept for a number of turns. The fact that gaining skills and growing in power actually affords new tactical opportunities rather than just embiggening numbers is one of this game's definite strengths. The huge amount of possible combinations of gear, stats, mutations and abilities mean that you'll have limitless options as to how to build your character.

Also rather unusually for a roguelike, this game has quests, and what appears to be a storyline. One downside is that those I've encountered so far appear to be fixed and do not vary from playthrough to playthrough, which does detract from the novelty a bit. I've not yet played far enough to tell for sure, but it does appear that they can be safely skipped, for the most part, though my compulsive nature has lead them to feeling more like chores to be repeated after each death rather than the interesting opportunities they were at first.

As for the simulation aspects, I'm not rightly sure how deep they go. It's certainly nowhere near Dwarf Fortress adventure mode's level of granular simulation, as numerous elements appear to stay the same across different playthroughs, and some things appear to not be simulated at all. This isn't a bad thing, however, since in lieu of DF's maniacal obsession with detail, this game provides basic gameplay mechanics that are far more fun, it runs better, and not having to rely on generated conversations and descriptions allows the devs to infuse it with far more flavour and atmosphere, creating an experience which is a lot more coherent and quite a bit less samey than DF's adventure mode.

Overall, I've played this game for only 4 hours as of writing this, and I've only explored a miniscule corner of the game world. If you like Roguelikes and RPGs in general, this game is a steal at 10 bucks. My only complaint is the unremovable CRT filter and the low contrast colour settings, which I've admittedly grown used to by now, but which I'd still rather turn off if I were given the option.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Think Cardinal Quest meets Brogue

~Features
Turn-based combat
ASCII graphics
Procedurally generated* world (*Static locations, such as the starting area.)
Impressive character creation / customization
Variety of enemies, NPCs, factions and races
Solid economy
Day and night cycle
Permadeath
Local high-scores / graveyard

Caves of Qud, despite forming a terrible acronym also forms a well-written and discursive love letter to the Rogue game, and the '-like' genre it spawned.

While heavily inspired by original rogue-likes (not least in its graphical style) it features the kind of complex, esoteric lore more commonly found in modern rogue-likes and '-lites'. With little to no explanation and zilch in the way of a tutorial, the game rewards trial and error, while laughing in the faces of those impatient or easily enraged.

The starting area of Joppa, is static and you will always start 'here', there are characters to talk to and some early missions to be had. Being the permadeath-fest that it is, the lack of a dynamic starting point may become repetitive to you, but I found it as a haven upon which to launch my next doomed-to-fail attempt, at discovering just what the hell I was supposed to be doing.
Joppa, described as an oasis-village, is such. A ray of familiarity in an otherwise blotched out world of unpredictability.

COQ (hehe), features heavy RPG elements and levelling is a requirement. This, in-spite of the frequent permadeath and subsequent character creation, never feels too 'grindy'.
I found myself encouraged to try one more run, rather than put off by a lacking sense of achievement.

Asking price is fair, in my opinion. Though edging on steep when judged against its competition. There is a free version (minus the minimalistic tile-set) floating about, so you can try before you commit to supporting its further development.

In conclusion, Caves of Qud is a true rogue-like with very few bells but a whole bag of whistles. For those with the constitution, a rich and open ended experience awaits.

This is a game that you can really sink your teeth into. The amount of hours you will get out of this is literally up to you.

What excites me the most about this is that it takes a more modern approach to the classic roguelike experience. So, you have the ASCII-ish graphics (there is a tileset, but it is primitive) mixed with sandbox gameplay that is *nearly* limitless with what you do and how you go about doing things. True-to-roguelike-form it is also hard as nails and rewards knowledge of previous play-throughs. Best of all, it is still in developement. This means we get to experience changes and new things as we play over time.

I particularly like the pseudo-switch from traditional 'magic' to 'mutations', and all that comes along with that.

Pros:
+Tileset is pretty sweet, and the devs have said there will be an option to switch them out to user-made sets
+Dialogue is well written, and is hand-crafted (compared to generated)
+Map is *nearly* infinite - but the best part is that most of it exists underground a la DF style!
+I particularly like using just a keyboard so I can lay in bed with a laptop and play (although mouse support will be added, as it is already in the menu options)
+The far-future universe is pretty cool!
+I actually really like the hunger/thirst system. Its balanced quite well so its not a grind. It also fits with the universe set in place (Mad Max-ish)

Cons:
-No music, yet, but obviously this will be implemented
-Need an option to zoom - as others have said - the tiles are a bit too small
-It may need some optimization for slightly slower machines
-Could benefit from an online leaderboard, or even the MSORPG chat elements in ToME

Having a modern roguelike of this nature, at this price, is simply amazing for any fan of the genre.

Have you ever wanted to play a computer RPG inspired by Gamma World? Have you ever wanted to load up a character creation screen and see pages upon pages of mutations to choose from for your character - everything from shooting fire from your hands, talking to machines, making psychic copies of yourself, multiple limbs and organs, and more than I could possibly summarize here? Doesn't sound fun? It is. If you manage to survive past the first screen, you will discover a world of ruins and remnants of an ancient, advanced civilization. You will fight with sword, bow, musket, and wild mutations, while trying to dechiper and deploy strange high tech artifacts from the past: grenades, shotguns, rifles, chemical injectors, turrets, and electronics.

High-tech ballistic weaponry meets bronze short swords and wooden bows.  Mutations, guns, water currency, artifacts, sentient plants -check! My enemies have a hard time hitting me without hurting themselves, so that's a plus.. I just wish I could hug somebody without impaling them on my spiky body. My spit is viscous and slimy, and there are pores on my body that release sleeping gas.  It's disgusting, I know, but these mutations have saved my skin more times than I care to remember.  I've gotten pretty good with an axe... I've gotten pretty good at killing.  Even I get surprised from time to time, and that's when I discovered that I can eject some of the quills from my body, which usually doesn't end well for anyone standing around me.

I'll admit that I've dabbled in different injectors from time to time.. the trick is to be smart about it and only take one at a time.. I mean, I'm not the brightest guy and even I figured that'd be a bad idea.  I've built up a pretty nice collection of gadgets thanks to some of the places I've visited, and some of the work I've done.. some of the people I've killed.

I'm still looking for my twin.. he and I have a score to settle.  I caught wind that he passed through Joppa a few weeks ago, and I've been tracking him ever since.  I think I'm getting close. Caves of Qud is a rogue-like RPG, but where it really shines is character creation and experimentation. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOh ♥♥♥♥
date:
I think to myself as crocodile bites into my flesh. I assumed that I could beat the glorified lizard like I could in so many other games. I was wrong. This was just the first of many deaths I would experience in my first couple of hours with the game.

TL;DR at the bottom.

I'm an unabashed fan of roguelikes. The focus on character building and death meaning something have always been a huge draw to me. If you look at my library, I have a lot of these suckers. You may wonder if there's still games in the genre that can still surprise me. The answer is HELL YES. Caves of Qud is one such game.

Throw out the typical fantasy setting you probably picture when you think of a roguelike. This is the post-apocalypse and your two choices are to play as a pure or mutated human. I've tried both and the latter seems to be way more fun. It kind of reminds me of the episodes of Futurama with the mutants in the sewer. You can turn yourself into all kinds of monstrosities, and I suspect the number of options will only grow over time. My most recent playthrough I decided to take a mutation which gave me flaming hands. I didn't realize it meant I would never be able to wear gloves. This is a great illustration of the mutation system: most of the time it involves trade offs, especially for the really fun powers, like being made up of quills like a porcupine (a personal favorite).

The graphics are ASC, but put through a filter that makes it look like you're playing on a much older computer. One that may or may not be from before your time. I personally love the look of it, but the result makes it deceptively system intensive.

The controls will be divisive to the say the least. Some will be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ that the controls are so obtuse, though once you play with them for a while they do start to feel natural. They can all be rebound though, and if you're willing to put in the effort to do so you can bind them in any way that your heart desires!

I haven't even explored a fraction of the world yet, nor have I managed to complete the first quest I was given. There are still enemies that would seem menial in other games that can kill me if I'm not careful. Call me a masochist but this is more than a little bit exciting to me. Two hours into a game I generally feel like I get what's going on, but here I'm still trying to figure out what exactly I'm supposed to do. The procedurally generated, fully destructable world is huge, and I get the feeling that even without permadeath (that is an option for those who are turned off by having to reroll all the time) the game would be collosal.

If you're into that kind of thing, there's tons of lore here too. More than I'll ever manage to sift through realistically. It's a world of mutants and sentient bears; the writing ain't half bad either.

Negatives are that the game uses far more system resources than it needs to. It looks pretty, but functionality trumps graphics, especially in a roguelike. Also, the game isn't friendly to those who aren't willing to be patient with it. You'll die a lot before you start to see successes. Then you'll continue to die frequently. That can be disheartening and will certainly put off some players. This game is harder than Nethack in my opinion, and that's not something I would say lightly. Tutorials would be a welcome feature, more than just a series of paragraphs to read in the help section.

TL;DR: This is the roguelike for the true hardcore roguelike player. It's tough, it's massive, and inventive enough that I feel like telling my friends about the porcupine-beetle-man hybrid that I rolled last time. For an early access title its chock full of content. Check it out, but just be ready to die.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What kind of game is it?
Caves of Qud is by most, if not all, definition a traditional rogue-like which features plenty of untimely deaths and tons of quirky living and non-living things. There are light elements of survival with some needs for food and water, and you are also able to make new stuffs if you happen to come across the 'data disk' for you and if you have the necessary skills. Being a traditional rogue-like also means graphics is restricted to ASCII or tiles (static icons effectively) so kindly do not expect to see the fringe of your character’s hair flowing in the breeze.

Is it fun?
Rogue-likes us]ed to exist at a time which requires people to use their imagination, and so it is only as fun as you imagine it to be. That said, the lack of graphics also mean more effort can be put into crafting deeper lore, additional content and balancing game mechanics instead of having to fiddle around with body proportions and rag-doll physics. Considering that you can choose to play a mutant with multiple hands, legs and heads (just two), perhaps it’s better not to fiddle around with the rag-doll physics too. Fun is when you actually make an effort to overcome an in-game obstacle and take pleasure in doing so, or when you prevent your next character’s death by learning from his/her predecessor’s demise. Fun is also when you are able to get randomized loot, crappy or otherwise, and make the most out of them. Fun too, is when you beat bad RNG odds to survive. Fun is all of the above; everything else is merely enjoyable at best.

Does it look good?
It looks as good-looking as alphabets and sentences can be. There’s quite a bit of reading to do, mostly flavor text and background lore and whether you might be dying or not, or did you lose a limb or two. Other than these, graphically-representative icons are all that you have to feed your imagination with.

Million dollar question (or whatever price the game is), is it worth buying?
There is a free ASCII version on the developer’s website (freeholdgames.com) which you may wish to download and check out for yourself on the content and gameplay. I would also advise watching a few Let’s Play episodes somewhere to gauge if you can dedicate the hours needed to enjoy the game. There are still some issues which needs to be ironed out, and the developer has been pretty hardworking so far to get these sorted out. All in all, still playable as it is, and the more hours you are willing to pour in, the more value for money the game is going to be.

Alright, time for a seriousness edit:

Caves of Qud is a traditional-style roguelike, set in a fallout-esque world a few thousand years after the end of the world. It's got plenty of procedurally generated caves and ruins to explore scattered across a large overworld, all tied together by a quest line rife with side-quests. At least, that's what it aims to be eventually; currently, the main quest line is not finished, and many side quests remain unimplemented as of the writing of this review. Despite this, there's tons of content to discover and die by.

Even though the quest line is unfinished, you will die many, many times before you reach the end (you'll know when it stops, if you make it that far). The difficulty and frequency of death allows you to explore the rich character creation system the game is packing. This system offers many options, allowing you to choose whether you begin as a mutant (slower skill point gain, but gains useful mutations) or a True Man (higher starting attributes, and increased skill point gain). From there, you've got a number of physical/mental mutations (for mutants) or castes (for True Men) to choose from. Additionally, Qud offers you a skill tree of sorts as you level up, allowing you to gain abilities as you grow more experienced. Oh, and dialogue trees!

Though it may be difficult to get in to, Caves of Qud offers a unique,engaging, and deeply rewarding rpg experience. I wholeheartedly recommend it to people interested in the genre, or to anyone interested in being mauled by a sleepy panther-bear because they spontaneously combusted while sneaking past it.

Caves of Qud's unique setting and character building options are what really makes it stand out from others in its genre. You start out in a water-farming town on the outskirts of a giant salt desert, performing tasks for villagers that are convinced their precious (even sacred) crops are being preyed upon by something mysterious. According to the developers, the world is influenced by Dune and Morrowind, among other interesting sources and the world reflects this in its alien atmosphere.

Character creation has tons of depth and I'm still trying to decide whether it's better to use my mutation points to fly around and toss grenades crafted from destroyed robots from the sky, or teleport up close and kill my enemies in bursts of quills sprouting from my body.

There's no doubt the game is difficult. After 10 hours, I've barely scratched the surface of the story as my character keeps dying in fresh and joyous ways. If you're new to roguelikes, be warned that they are completely unforgiving. Compared to others in the genre, Caves of Qud provides more intuitive controls and a less overwhelming character creation. Still, it's tough getting started. However the initial unfamiliarity with the game's mechanics will go away, if you're willing to die a few dozen times.

As someone who plays a lot of Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup, I came to this game with high expectations. There is a lot of depth of gameplay here, but you're constantly fighting against the User Interface and the way the map works more than the monsters themselves.

You will constantly find yourself bumping into walls you can't see because rather than keeping the game world centered on the player, you're going from screen to screen. It feels very clunky and it constantly takes me out of the experience. There is a giant box of information to one side of the screen that blocks a huge portion of the map, but for how big it is, it really doesn't tell you a whole lot.

Another annoyance is the auto-explore AI. It is extremely poor. It skips over items you have on auto-pickup, and it's constantly getting stuck on nothing when the screen is nowhere near fully explored.

The game also seemed to discourage exploring too deep into any given cave - there are dead ends everywhere, and no easy way to backtrack like in most roguelikes. I was very disappointed that there didn't seem to be any way to get back to the surface other than the way I came, forcing me to try to retrace my steps over an hour and a half.

Another issue I had with the game is the performance - you would think such a simple looking game would run smooth as silk, but this game has to stop and think an awful lot. I didn't get far into the game and the files it generated on my computer total up to 385MB - 60MB for the save file, 60MB for a backup of that save file, and an enormous amount of cache. Like many early access titles, this game really needs some optimization done to it, but it's just surprising to see it from a game like this.

I feel like the entire engine needs to be rebuilt from the ground up, getting rid of the per-screen nonsense and keeping the world centered on the player, and with a much better User Interface. I really wanted to like this game, but I just don't. It needs to be better.

This game is excellent. I'm a longtime classic roguelike fan: NetHack, ToME, Brogue, Sil. I also love a lot of modern ones: SotS the Pit, FTL, Isaac. This game is so immersive and hits all the right roguelike buttons that I will undoubtedly spend hundreds of hours in this game. It also updates UI and concepts to be in line with modern notions of great game design.

The character creation alone is the best I've played. I can't imagine running out of fun and interesting new ways to play the game. Even if I get so good I can run the game with a bunch of obvious builds, there are tons of ways to keep making it challenging. Each tweak makes the game totally different.

The tiles are beautiful. The story is fascinating (by story, I mean the fact that relationships between different groups are procedurally generated). I understand putting off getting this until it moves out of early access, but you should know that it is fully worth the price as is.

After surviving the journey into redrock, defeating my evil twin, and claiming a home in joppa for myself, i came across a very irritable tortoise. Seeing the untaped potential within, i made him my disciple and gave him a shotgun. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shot me in the back in the next fight. obviously being a tortoise, he shoots like Cheney. with that lesson learned, i gave him some chainmail and took back my gun and we went on our merry way. where he murdered everything in sight.

Of all the rogue likes ive played, Caves of Qud is by far one of the best of the Classic/tradition styles. only really topped by Dwarf Fortress in depth in both story and similation. while you may not be able to throw a rabbit with enough force to decaptitate a cyclops, you can freeze it solid and shoot it with a rocket launcher.

Of course the only real flaw with the game for the genre, is being of the classic style, it has archaic controls, being pretty much completely keyboard based. (part of the charm in my book, but it can get annoying at times)

Another issue you may come across (besides the genre specific issues such as difficulty) would be figuring out whats going on at times. the tiles are amazing and make things significantly easier, but they still dont stop the age old issue of too much clutter. I've had many a character die because i didnt realize that an enemy aproached me, or was even on screen, though a simple fix for this would be to highlight hostile NPCs.

the only other issue new players may run into, would be the simple lack of ingame information. some of it can be obtained through books and such ingame, but many things such as mutations developed after starting a character, have no info to them, thus having the wiki or google up is a must for all but the most veteran of players.

In summary, if you love classic rogue likes, like dwarf fort, this game is a must have, however it has the same issues and complexity that plagues that part of the genre. if you are on the fence still, or are new to the genre, i'd highly recomend watching some youtube videos before purchase, the genre isnt for everyone.

Early Access Review

Traditional roguelike meets modern RPG, with a novel setting for a roguelike (far-future). It's really nicely put together, well polished and with great writing. If the concept appeals to you then you'll probably enjoy it; I don't think there are any nasty surprises. Only thing I will say is that permadeath doesn't really feel right here - but you can turn it off, so it's not really a complaint.

Looking forward to seeing how development pans out!
